text:
Diapsalmata
I have just now come from a party where I was its life and soul; witticisms streamed from my lips, everyone laughed and admired me, but I went away — yes, the dash should be as long as the radius of the earth's orbit ——————————— and wanted to shoot myself.
What is a poet? An unhappy man who in his heart harbors a deep anguish, but whose lips are so fashioned that the sighs and cries which pass over them are transformed into ravishing music.
I do not care for anything. I do not care to ride, for the exercise is too violent. I do not care to walk, for it is too strenuous. I do not care to lie down, for I should either have to remain lying, and I do not care to do that, or I should have to get up again, and I do not care to do that either. Summa summarum: I do not care at all.
My life is like an eternal night...
The Rotation of Crops
People with experience maintain that proceeding from a basic principle is the supposed starting point for all consistent thinking. I am told that this is also the case in the world of high finance, although I have no personal acquaintance with it. I am told that a bankrupt not only has lost everything but also has lost his honor, and that to have kept his honor is the only thing that can help him to start a new business.
The unhappiest man! He who is always waiting, who never lives in the present, but always in the future or the past.

Preface
Not only in the world of commerce but also in the world of ideas our age has arranged a regular clearance sale. Everything is to be had at such a bargain that it is questionable whether in the end there is anybody who will want to buy. Every speculative waiter-boy puts down his napkin and says, "Our age calls for the realization of the universal," and the waiter-boy in the cafe responds, "To be sure, the demand of the age must be heard."
I. A Panegyric upon Abraham
If there were no eternal consciousness in a man, if at the foundation of all there lay only a wildly seething power which writhing with obscure passions produced everything that is great and everything that is insignificant, if a bottomless void never satiated lay hidden beneath all--what then would life be but despair? If it were thus, if there were no sacred bond which united mankind, if one generation arose after another like the leafage of the forest, if the one generation replaced the other like the song of birds in the forest, if the human race passed through the world as the ship goes through the sea, like the wind through the desert, a thoughtless and fruitless activity, if an eternal oblivion were always lurking hungrily for its prey and there were no power strong enough to wrest it from its maw--how empty then and comfortless life would be!
But therefore it is not thus...
Abraham I cannot understand, in a certain sense I can learn nothing from him but astonishment. If people fancy that by considering the outcome of this story they might let themselves be moved to believe that it would be so with them, they deceive themselves and would cheat God of the first movement of faith, giving Him the second instead.
The knight of faith is obliged to rely upon himself alone, he feels the pain of not being able to make himself intelligible to others, but he feels no vain desire to guide others. The pain is his assurance that he is in the right path, the absence of it is the proof that he is not.
To exist as the individual is the most terrible thing of all.
